channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Kevin Warsh, a central-bank insider-turned-critic, is Trump’s choice to succeed Jerome Powell as Federal Reserve chair
item.description: The pick to succeed Jerome Powell spent years positioning himself for the job—and years publicly attacking the institution that he is poised to head.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Kevin Warsh’s nomination to lead the Federal Reserve marks a triumphant return to the central bank for a former Fed official who has long angled for the Fed’s top job
item.description: As a young man, the nominee took a starring role at the central bank, and he has angled for years to lead it.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Eurozone Economy Posts Resilient 2025 Growth Despite Tariff Turbulence
item.description: The eurozone economy last year expanded at its fastest pace since 2022 despite higher U.S. tariffs, and seems set for continued modest growth.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: Taiwan’s Economy Grew at Fastest Pace in 15 Years
item.description: The Taiwanese economy expanded at the fastest pace since 2010 last year as it cashed in on the artificial-intelligence boom.
item.dc:creator: Sherry Qin

item.title: President Trump’s advisers have been told that he is expected to nominate Kevin Warsh, a central bank insider-turned-critic, as Federal Reserve chair, according to people familiar with the matter
item.description: The president said he plans to announce his choice to succeed Jerome Powell as Fed chair on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Alex Leary

item.title: Tokyo Inflation Slows in New Signal for BOJ
item.description: Inflation signals have taken on more significance as yen weakness poses a risk to the Bank of Japan’s efforts to generate healthy, demand-led price growth.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: China Agrees to Lower Tariffs by Half on U.K. Whisky
item.description: The U.K. government said it expects whisky exports to China to be worth roughly $345.2 million to the economy over the next five years as tariffs are lowered to 5% from 10%.
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: After pandemic-era hiring binges, big companies from Amazon.com to UPS are slashing jobs, looking to shrink their head counts after years of breakneck growth
item.description: Many corporations binged on labor during the pandemic. Now, facing economic uncertainty and AI threats, they are slimming down.
item.dc:creator: Chip Cutter

item.title: South African Reserve Bank Keeps Key Rate Unchanged
item.description: The Reserve Bank maintained its main repo rate at 6.75% as it weighed steady inflation, low oil prices and a stronger rand against global geopolitical uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: U.S. Jobless Claims Remain Subdued Last Week
item.description: The number of people who filed for unemployment benefits fell to 209,000 in the week through Jan. 24, down from 210,000 a week earlier, the Labor Department said.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Coacci

item.title: U.S. Trade Deficit Grew in November
item.description: The U.S. trade deficit rebounded in November, the Commerce Department said Thursday, extending a turbulent stretch for international trade flows as the economy responds to the Trump administration’s tariffs and financial volatility.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Irish Economy Soared in 2025 on Weight-Loss Drugs Boom
item.description: Ireland’s GDP was 12.6% higher on year, the fastest expansion since 2021, even as Trump raised tariffs on imports from Europe and urged businesses to bring their production to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Sweden’s Central Bank Holds Key Rate, Doesn’t Expect Change Any Time Soon
item.description: The Riksbank kept its key policy rate at 1.75%. Policymakers have now held steady for three consecutive meetings.
item.dc:creator: Dominic Chopping

item.title: U.K. Property Market Recovers Post-Budget Jitters But Price Growth Still Slow
item.description: House prices rose at a slower pace in 2025 compared with the year before, as uncertainty about the government’s budget plans weighed on buyer demand.
item.dc:creator: Anthony O. Goriainoff

item.title: A 1990s initiative to replace housing projects with mixed-income developments gave children an economic lift as adults, new research finds
item.description: A 1990s government initiative to replace housing projects with mixed-income developments gave children an economic lift as adults, new research finds.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s decision on whether to remain on the central bank’s board after his chairmanship ends is the last and only card he holds against the Trump administration
item.description: The Fed chair has been asked four times whether he will stay on the board after his term as chair is up. His silence is the strategy.
item.dc:creator: Josh Dawsey

item.title: Singapore’s Central Bank Stays on Hold as It Raises Inflation Forecasts
item.description: Singapore’s central bank kept monetary-policy settings steady at its first meeting of the year, forecasting hotter inflation and relatively solid growth.
item.dc:creator: Fabiana Negrin Ochoa

item.title: Brazil’s Central Bank Holds Rate High, Signals March Cut
item.description: The bank’s monetary policy committee kept the nation’s benchmark rate at 15%, while indicating it may start cutting at its next meeting in March.
item.dc:creator: Paulo Trevisani

item.title: American farmers hope to benefit from a U.S.-Malaysia trade deal, but finding buyers in a fiercely competitive landscape isn’t straightforward
item.description: American farmers hope to benefit from a U.S.-Malaysia trade deal, but finding buyers in a fiercely competitive landscape isn’t straightforward.
item.dc:creator: Gabriele Steinhauser

item.title: Consumer Confidence Dropped to 12-Year Low in January, per Conference Board
item.description: The monthly survey’s primary index dropped from 94.2 in December to 84.5 in January as the economic mood worsened across ages and income levels.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: India and the European Union have reached a free-trade agreement that will open a new market for European cars and other products
item.description: The agreement is both economies’ largest and will link almost two billion consumers.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Spanish Unemployment Fell in Final Quarter of 2025
item.description: The number of unemployed people fell by 136,100 to 2.48 million, the country’s statistics body, INE said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Rocked by growth-sapping shocks, countries around the world are rolling out large fiscal stimulus packages financed by bumper budget deficits
item.description: Rearmament, an aging population, technological change and fear of voters are fueling a risky trend.
item.dc:creator: Tom Fairless

item.title: The build-to-rent business looks poised to take off after President Trump exempted the industry from his regulations on large investors
item.description: The build-to-rent business looks poised to take off after Trump exempted this industry from his regulations on large investors.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Improved in January, Michigan Survey Finds
item.description: Consumers felt a bit better about the economy in January as sentiment lifted off from near-historical lows reached late last year, according to the University of Michigan’s monthly survey.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Business Activity Picks Up in Parts of Europe and Asia
item.description: Business activity in the U.S. and a number of large economies across Europe and Asia picked up at the start of the year, with signs of a rebound in export orders as the global economy adjusts to the increase in U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.K. Consumer Mood Improves Despite Economic Clouds
item.description: Consumer sentiment rose slightly in January, though confidence over the U.K.’s economic outlook remains subdued.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Lutnick Says Europe Overreacted Over Greenland
item.description: The U.S. commerce secretary also criticized Canada’s move to further its trade relationship with China.
item.dc:creator: Joe Stonor

item.title: Jobless Claims Show No Red Flags
item.description: U.S. jobless claims ticked slightly higher last week but remain subdued, signaling little reason to fret that the labor market has worsened abruptly.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: ECB Rate Setters Considered Argument for a Further Cut
item.description: Some members of the governing council said at December’s meeting that there could be a case for erring on the dovish side.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Google searches for “No Buy January” have hit a five-year high as Gen Zers and millennials sign up for the thrifty challenge
item.description: Google searches for “No Buy January” have hit a five-year high as Gen-Zers and millennials sign up for the thrifty challenge.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cooper

item.title: President Trump issued an executive order on Tuesday laying out steps to stop Wall Street home purchases
item.description: President issued an executive order on Tuesday that laid out steps to stop Wall Street home purchases.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Picciotto

item.title: Escalating tensions over Greenland are supercharging a dynamic that was already under way: a shift in the world economic order that had put the U.S. at the center of the global economy
item.description: The U.S. has long been a beacon of safety when uncertainty reigns. That is changing.
item.dc:creator: Sam Goldfarb

item.title: Heard on the Street: Conflicting interests make it hard for policymakers to give young Americans a leg up in a brutal housing market
item.description: Young Americans need home prices to fall. Existing owners don’t want to take a hit.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Economists will tell you that it is a tough time for people entering the job market. They can relate: It is the worst market young economists have faced in memory.
item.description: Newly minted Ph.D.s tend to work for universities, government agencies and big white-collar companies. It’s not a great hiring time for any of them.
item.dc:creator: Justin Lahart

item.title: Inflation slowed over the course of 2025, but Americans remain frustrated that they haven’t seen more relief on prices, particularly at the grocery store
item.description: Gasoline prices are down, but rising grocery costs continue to weigh on consumers.
item.dc:creator: Drew An-Pham
